docs.title: π.works
docs.text: Greetings, and thank you for visiting this blog. My name is Jianan Li, and I'm a PhD student focusing on (aerial) robotics and (multi-agent) reinforcement learning at Westlake University. This platform serves to share the progress and insights of my research. As I approach the end of my doctoral studies, I am currently enthusiastic to explore career opportunities.

docs.title: Featured Research 1:  Target Pursuit
docs.text:
Click the figure to see more.

This GIF shows an experimental flight scenario in which the pursuer aerial vehicle employs the proposed uniform bearing-only pseudo linear Kalman filter to estimate the target state, while simultaneously utilizing helical navigation guidance to track the target. This work has been published in IEEE Transactions on Robotics (T-RO, top jounal in robotics).

PDF | Youtube | Bilibili | Very useful Kalman filter

docs.title: Featured Research 2:  Predator-Prey Swarming
docs.text:
Click the figure to see more.

This research project explores the interesting topic of why and how do animals form swarming behaviors. The GIF shows our findings that how simple predator-prey survival pressure (prey receive a reward of -1 if caught by predators while predators receive a reward of +1 ) is sufficient to evolve various swarming behaviors. The Video abstract on Bilibili hit 10,000 views within 3 days (B站点击量3天破万). The paper is also selected by the Journal as one of the "Top Ten Most Read Papers”.

PDF-official | PDF-two-column version in arXiv | Youtube | Bilibili

docs.title: Featured Research 3:  Athletic Intelligence
docs.text: This is one of my on-going research projects related to athletic intelligence. We employ reinforcement learning techniques to facilitate the training of legged robots in the art of walking.

docs.title: About Me
docs.text:
Greetings, and thank you for visiting this blog. My name is Jianan Li, and I'm a PhD student focusing on (aerial) robotics and (multi-agent) reinforcement learning at Westlake University located in Hangzhou, China. This platform serves to share the progress and insights of my research. As I approach the end of my doctoral studies, I am currently enthusiastic to explore career opportunities.

Research Projects Summary

Education & Work Experience
  • Ph.D. Candidate at Westlake University & Zhejiang U.
    • Research Area: (Aerial) Robotics, (Multiagent) Reinforcement Learning, (Bearing-Only) Kalman Filter
  • Research Associate at Air Traffic Management Research Institute (ATMRI), Singapore.
  • MSc. in Aerospace Engineering at Nanyang Technological University, Singapore
    • Research Area: Visual Servoing of Quadrotors
  • BSc. in Electromechanical Engineering at University of Macau, Macao, China.
    • Exchanged to National Chiao Tung U & Tsinghua U, Taiwan; University of California, Berkeley, CA, USA.
Skills
  • (Multiagent) Reinforcement Learning: Mathematics in ML & RL; Familiar with PyTorch framework.
  • (Aerial) Robotics: Familiar with quadrotor dynamics, linear & nonlinear control, guidance law, Kalman filter, coordinate transformation, pin-hole camera model, visual servoing; Familiar with Matlab/Simulink
  • Development: Familiar with GNU/Linux, C++, Python, ROS
  • Languages: Mandarin, English, local dialects of Ningbo & Shanghai
Why π.works ?

My name is often abbreviated as J. Li, with J representing the first letter of my given name and L for the first letter of my surname. When merged, they form JL, resembling the Greek letter π and symbolizing the irrational number Pi. This is the inspiration behind π.works.

Contact info

Feel free to contact me via lijianan [at] westlake.edu.cn if you have any questions.

My 100m breaststroke record in middle school

docs.title: Three Dimensional Bearing-Only Target Following via Observability-Enhanced Helical Guidance
docs.text: If the Bilibili video fails to load, consider using a VPN or directly visiting Youtube | Bilibili.

docs.title: Abstract
docs.text:
This paper studies the problem of air-to-air target following of micro aerial vehicles (MAVs) motivated by the defense against malicious MAVs. When the bearing of the target MAV can be measured by onboard visual sensors of the pursuer MAV, the problem becomes three-dimensional (3D) bearing-only target following, which has been rarely studied in the literature and faces some unique challenges. To solve this problem, we propose a series of novel results on target estimation, observability analysis, and observability enhancement. The novelty of the results is summarized as follows.

First, in order to estimate the motion of the target MAV from 3D bearing measurements, we propose a new pseudo-linear Kalman filter, which has a concise expression yet superior stability properties compared to the classic ones including the conventional extended Kalman filter and modified polar coordinate filter.

Second, we propose a novel approach to analyze the observability of state estimate of the target when only bearing information is available. While the existing ones by optimizing the determinant of Fisher information matrix are applicable to 2D single-step horizon cases, our approach can handle more general 3D multiple-step horizon cases.

Third, based on the theoretical conclusion of our observability analysis, we design a new 3D helical guidance law that can better exploit the additional degree of freedom in 3D. The guidance law is adapted to quadcopter's dynamics and a low-level flight controller is designed based on geometric control.

Extensive numerical simulation results verify the superior performance of the proposed algorithms compared to the state-of-the-art ones. Flight experiments on real quadrotor platforms further show the effectiveness and robustness of the proposed algorithms in practice.

docs.title: Derivation of u-PLKF
docs.text:
Quite useful result !

This section introduces a novel bearing-only uniform pseudo-linear Kalman filter (u-PLKF) to estimate the position and velocity of the target from noisy bearing measurements in 3D.

State Transition

Denote the states of the target and pursuer as \(x_T=[p_T^T,v_T^T]^T \in \mathbb{R}^6\) and \(x_P=[p^T,v^T]^T \in \mathbb{R}^6\), respectively. Here, \(x_P\) is known and \(x_T\) is to be estimated. The discrete double-integrator dynamics of the states are described by $$ x_{T,k} = Ax_{T,k-1} + Bq_k $$ $$ x_{P,k} = Ax_{P,k-1} + Bu_k $$

where $$ A = egin{bmatrix} I_{3 imes 3} & \Delta tI_{3 imes 3} \ 0_{3 imes 3} & I_{3 imes 3} \end{bmatrix}, $$ $$ B = egin{bmatrix} rac{1}{2}\Delta t^2 I_{3 imes 3} \ \Delta t I_{3 imes 3} \end{bmatrix}, $$

and \(\Delta t\) is the sampling time. Here, \(u_k\in \mathbb{R}^3\) is the control input of the pursuer, \(q_k\) is a process noise drawn from a zero-mean normal distribution, that is,\(q_k \sim \mathcal{N}(0,Q_k)\) where we assume the acceleration of the target is unknown.

Subtracting the above two equations leads to the dynamical equation of the relative state \(x=x_T-x_P\): $$ x_k = Ax_{k-1} - Bu_k + Bq_k. $$ The term \(Bu_k\) could be calculated by \(Bu_k=x_{P,k}-Ax_{P,k-1}\).

Measurement Equation

While \(p\) and \(p_T\) are the position of the pursuer and target MAVs, respectively, we know that $$ \lambda = rac{p_T - p}{||p_T - p||} $$ is a unit vector representing the relative bearing of the target with respect to the pursuer. In our work, we use the unit vector instead of angles to represent 3D bearings to avoid complicated trigonometric functions.

In practice, we are only able to obtain a noise-corrupted bearing, denoted as \( ilde{\lambda}\): $$ ilde{\lambda} = \lambda + u $$ where \( u \in \mathbb{R}^3\) is the measurement noise assumed to be normally distributed: \( u \sim \mathcal{N}(0, \Sigma), \Sigma = \sigma^2 I_{3 imes 3}\).

It is noticed that \( ilde{\lambda}\) is a nonlinear function of \(p_T\). In order to obtain a linear measurement equation, we introduce an orthogonal projection operator. For any nonzero vector \(g\in \mathbb{R}^3\), define $$ P_g = I_{3 imes3} - rac{g}{|g|} rac{g^T}{|g|} $$ The interpretation of \(P_g\) is that, for any vector \(z \in \mathbb{R}^3\), its orthogonal projection onto the plane perpendicular to \(g\) is \(P_g z\). The matrix \(P_g\) satisfies \(P_g=P_g^T\), \(P_g^2 = P_g\) and \( ext{ker}(P_g) = ext{span}(g)\).

Multiplying \(rP_{ ilde{\lambda}}\) on both sides of \( ilde{\lambda} = \lambda + u\) gives $$ 0_{3 imes 1} = P_{ ilde{\lambda}}(p_T-p) + rP_{ ilde{\lambda}} u $$ where \(r=||p_T-p||\) and the left-hand side is zero because \(P_{ ilde{\lambda}} ilde{\lambda} = 0\). Thus, the nonlinear bearing function becomes a pseudo-linear equation. Furthermore, since the relative state to be estimated is \(x:=[(p-p_T)^T, (v-v_T)^T]^T\in\mathbb{R}^6\), the final measurement equation is obtained as $$ 0_{3 imes 1} = egin{bmatrix} P_{ ilde{\lambda}} & 0_{3 imes 3} \end{bmatrix} x + rP_{ ilde{\lambda}} u. $$ Note \( u\) is assumed to be normally distributed and the term \(rP_{ ilde{\lambda}}\) can be considered as a time-varying noise transition matrix. By inspection we can conclude this transition depends on the true range \(r\) and the orientation of the vector \( ilde{\lambda}\). One problem for estimating the noise transition matrix is that the true range \(r\) is not known in practice, so in the filter we replace \(r\) with a predicted one. Such replacement has been used in other research works and verified to be effective in our simulation and experimental results.

Overall u-PLKF

The steps of the proposed 3D bearing-only uniform pseudo-linear Kalman filter (u-PLKF) is summarized below.

The prediction step is

\[ \hat{x}_k^- = A(\hat{x}_{k-1} + x_{P,k-1}) - x_{P,k} \]

$$ P_k^- = AP_{k-1}A^T + BQ_kB^T $$ where \(\hat{x}_k^-\) and \(P_k^-\) are the priori state estimate and error covariance.

The correction step is $$ K_k = P_k^-H_k^T(H_kP_k^-H_k^T+V_k\Sigma V_k^T)^{\dagger} $$

\[ \hat{x}_k = \hat{x}_k^- -K_kH_k\hat{x}_k^- \] \[ P_k = (I_{6 imes 6}-K_kH_k)P_k^- \]

where \(H_k = egin{bmatrix} P_{ ilde{\lambda}_k} & 0_{3 imes 3} \end{bmatrix}\), \(K_k\) is the observer gain, \(V_k = \hat{r}_k^-P_{ ilde{\lambda}_k}\) and \(\hat{r}_k^-\) is simply the norm of the first three components of \(\hat{x}_k^-\),\(\hat{x}_k\) and \(P_k\) are the posterior state estimate and error covariance, and symbol \(\dagger\) denotes the pseudo-inverse. The reason for using pseudo-inverse is that the matrix \((H_kP_k^-H_k^T+V_k\Sigma V_k^T)\) is rank deficient since \(P_{ ilde{\lambda}_k}\) in \(H_k\) is rank deficient. The usage of pseudo-inverse in the Kalman filter is a common practice when the inverse does not exist.

Denote \(z_k\) as the measurement in a classic Kalman filter. According to the measurement equation, it is noticeable that in our model \(z_k\) is actually \(0_{3 imes 1}\). With \(z_k=0_{3 imes 1}\), the standard step of updating the posterior estimate \(\hat{x}_k\) is thus reduced as follows: $$ \hat{x}_k = \hat{x}_k^- +K_k(z_k - H_k\hat{x}_k^- ) = \hat{x}_k^- -K_kH_k\hat{x}_k^-. $$

Actually, the measurement information has been implicitly contained in matrix \(H_k\), and this is also where the name pseudo-linear comes from because \(H_k\) is varying. In addition, the observation matrix \(H_k\) has the same mathematical expression in both 2D and 3D cases. Particularly, \(H_k\) can be written as \(H_k = egin{bmatrix} P_{ ilde{\lambda}_k} & 0_{d imes d} \end{bmatrix}\) where \( ilde{\lambda} \in \mathbb{R}^d\) and \(d\) is space dimension which can be \(2\) or \(3\). By contrast, the observation matrices for common EKF methods have more complicated expressions when dimension is lifted from 2 to 3. This is how the name uniform PLKF, or u-PLKF is coined as.

Note

Use this concise result in your Kalman filter design ! Feel free to contact me if you have any questions.

docs.title: Image-Based Visual Servoing of Rotorcrafts to Planar Visual Targets of Arbitrary Orientation
docs.text: If the YouTube video fails to load, consider using a network proxy or directly visiting YouTube.

docs.title: Abstract
docs.text:
This letter for the first time extends the virtual camera image-based visual servoing (IBVS) scheme to enable an underactuated rotorcraft UAV to regulate its translational motion and heading relative to a planar visual target of arbitrary orientation. The conversion from real camera images to virtual camera images of visual targets are proposed based on a set of rotation matrices. Hence, image moment features can be reused due to the simplicity and decoupled structure of the interaction matrix, and satisfactory 3D Cartesian trajectory of UAVs.

In the design of the IBVS control law, the external disturbance and model uncertainties are estimated by an integral-based filter. In addition, to enable tracking of a moving visual target, a velocity estimator is developed. The global asymptotic stability of the error dynamics is proven. Both of the simulation and experimental results of tracking of a tilted moving planar target are provided to show the efficacy of the proposed IBVS scheme.

docs.title: A Nonlinear Trajectory Tracking Controller for Helicopters: Design and Experimental Evaluation
docs.text: If the YouTube video fails to load, consider using a network proxy or directly visiting YouTube.

docs.title: Abstract
docs.text: This paper addresses the design and experimental evaluation of a controller to steer a helicopter along a desired trajectory. The controller is designed based on Lyapunov’s method and backstepping technique. Control laws for thrust and angular velocity are presented that guarantee the convergence of the trajectory tracking error to zero for a simplified helicopter model. Experimental results, which include the helicopter tracking an ellipse, are presented to assess the validity and performance of the proposed controller.

docs.title: Output Feedback Image-Based Visual Servoing of Rotorcrafts
docs.text: If the YouTube video fails to load, consider using a network proxy or directly visiting YouTube.

docs.title: Abstract
docs.text:
This paper presents an improved output feedback based image-based visual servoing (IBVS) law for rotorcraft unmanned aerial vehicles (RUAVs). The control law enables a RUAV with a minimal set of sensors, i.e. an inertial measurement unit (IMU) and a single downward facing camera, to regulate its position and heading relative to a planar visual target consisting of multiple points.

As compared to our previous work, twofold improvement is made. First, the desired value of the image feature of controlling the vertical motion of the RUAV is a function of other image features instead of a constant. This modification helps to keep the visual target stay in the camera’s field of view by indirectly adjusting the height of the vehicle. Second, the proposed approach simplifies our previous output feedback law by reducing the dimension of the observer filter state space while the same asymptotic stability result is kept. Both simulation and experimental results are presented to demonstrate the performance of the proposed controller

docs.title: Predator-prey survival pressure is sufficient to evolve swarming behaviors
docs.text:
中文English

Click the “中文/English” tab above to switch languages. If the video fails to load, consider using a VPN or directly visiting Youtube | Bilibili.

docs.title: Abstract
docs.text:
The comprehension of how local interactions arise in global collective behavior is of utmost importance in both biological and physical research. Traditional agent-based models often rely on static rules that fail to capture the dynamic strategies of the biological world. Reinforcement learning has been proposed as a solution, but most previous methods adopt handcrafted reward functions that implicitly or explicitly encourage the emergence of swarming behaviors.

In this study, we propose a minimal predator-prey coevolution framework based on mixed cooperative-competitive multiagent reinforcement learning, and adopt a reward function that is solely based on the fundamental survival pressure, that is, prey receive a reward of -1 if caught by predators while predators receive a reward of +1. Surprisingly, our analysis of this approach reveals an unexpectedly rich diversity of emergent behaviors for both prey and predators, including flocking and swirling behaviors for prey, as well as dispersion tactics, confusion, and marginal predation phenomena for predators. Overall, our study provides novel insights into the collective behavior of organisms and highlights the potential applications in swarm robotics.

docs.title: Resources
docs.text:
PDF-official | PDF-two-column version in arXiv | Youtube | Bilibili

As per the request of numerous researchers, the code for this project is set to be released in early 2024, upon the completion of my doctoral thesis. Nevertheless, reproducing the results of this project should be straightforward, as no advanced algorithms involved (only vanilla DDPG). If you have any questions, please directly contact me via lijianan [at] westlake.edu.cn.

By the way, the PDF-two-column version on arXiv contains identical content to the official PDF, but it's presented in a more condensed format, potentially making it easier for you to read.
